Posts.Content: Hello to December's crew! Midway between cycles 3 and 4 and I am beginning to notice the build up if side effects. Nothing major - a niggly sore throat, a bit of nausea here and there, but this month I have noticed that my hands are shaking more frequently. Not major like if I had Parkinsons, but enough that my shopping list looks like a doctor's prescription! Also means that I can't occupy myself with my major hobbies of sewing or cross stitch! So I'm getting antsy about it all now!  As both times i have been to see the oncologist, he has said that my WBC count has been low I went out and bought a marrow bone to make some beef broth this week! We'll see if that makes any difference! Good luck to anyone on chemo this week
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: I'm here too until January! Had my third dose of FEC last week, and been feeling a bit low. But tried to keep cheery by thinking I was 50% done with all this c**p! Now I have to wait until 12th Dec for my first of 3 Docetaxel sessions, and they scare me even more! Still onwards and upwards as they say!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: PinkLadyH I've had a day like that too today. Nothing tastes right!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Merry Christmas to all here. Hope your taste buds have returned for the day at least!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Went to hospital yesterday for my oncologist clinic - appt at 9.40. At 10.30 a nurse comes out to say that he had been delayed - she wasn't sure why, but advised everyone to stay put. Finally the unit manager informed us 10 minutes later that he would not be coming, but they would get one of the other oncologists to cover his clinic, so please be patient! Got seen FINALLY about 11.20 by a doctor who looked about 12! Surprise, surprise that my WBC is low AGAIN! (Has been on every session! She agreed that I should have a reduced dose on my first Docetaxel, but I have to have the injections! However she wanted me to have more blood tests! So I wandered over to that department and sat there until nearly half past 12! And then they had trouble getting blood, so she passed me over to another "vampire" who finally managed to get enough blood out! So a quick clinic trip turned into a whole morning's "adventure"! And I still have to turn up tomorrow not knowing if I'll get my first Docetaxel treatment or not! Hope everyone else's week turns out better than mine! X
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Semh I'd be really interested to know about your side effects from Docetaxel. Send me a message if you'd prefer? Last night I gave myself the first injection - something I was dreading! The injection wasn't too bad though as I did it just before bed and dropped off to sleep quite quickly. However I woke about 4 times overnight - couple of loo trips, but general aches and pains and also pain just over my breast bone. Incidentally my nurse told me not to clean the clean with an antiseptic wipe but to use clean water to clean the skin and dry before injecting.  However today when I got up, I felt really dizzy! Lasted about an hour. Still feel weak, but temperature not raised, so just going to take some paracetamol to see if that can help. Doesn't help either that we suddenly have no hot water this afternoon, so got to sit and wait for an engineer to call as an emergency appointment! I was lucky with my FEC cycles. Although I had a bit of nausea and headaches (and night sweats with the steroids) on the whole I didn't suffer too much. I had a runny nose and bit of a sore throat too, but they seemed to be more a symptom of my neutropenia rather than the FEC!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Semh thanks for listing what you went through! Most of what you describe, I had already had with my FEC cycles! My nose has run virtually constantly since day 1! I had a few days where I had a nose bleed too, but my nurses weren't worried! I am so tired after just 4 of those injections! But when I get to bed I wake up about 2am and then can't get back to sleep! Today I dozed off again at some point, waking at 9.30! Then I dozed again! And bedtime has slowly crept forward to about 9pm too! My metallic taste has reappeared, and my appetite has disappeared completely! I'm trying to eat little and often, but some days I just don't want to eat anything. I have to remind myself to keep drinking as I know I don't drink enough on a normal basis. I seem to have developed a taste for orange juice mixed with lemonade, so I'm going with that.  My left hand in particular seems sore - chemo nurse seemed to think it was because I'm not drinking enough - she described it as similar to gout! Since starting the injections, I have had pains in my right armpit (where my lymph nodes were removed), a pain across the top of my chest and pains in my left thigh - but I'm told they are just the filgrastim doing it's job! And to add insult to injury today I woke up with terrific stomach cramp - eventually alleviated by sitting on the toilet for half an hour! My WBC has been low throughout all my chemo (I spent 6 nights in Hotel NHS on cycle one), so I am trying to do everything by the book now as I really don't want to end up there over Christmas/New Year!  Hope you tolerate the EC treatment okay.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Yesterday I had my first Docetaxel (cycle 4 of 6). Currently only night sweats and minor headache just like with FEC. But the dreaded injections start tonight, so I am going to go to bed early just in case!  So been out shopping today in case I don't feel like it tomorrow.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Evening all! I hope that those on treatment this week are feeling okay (or at least not too bad!) I really suffered today - we went shopping and got the last bits of food shopping. I came home, put the food away and went to bed! I have felt so tired since starting the Docetaxel last week! The injections haven't been as bad as I feared, but still I ache from head to toe! Last night I had chest pains, not as bad as when I was in Hotel NHS, but still bad enough to wake me and keep me awake for a couple of hours. So far though the occasional paracetamol has kept most of the pain at bay. Tonight is the last injection, so hopefully we can start to pick up before Christmas itself. Good luck everyone - remember every day is one day nearer the end of your treatment!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: This afternoon, I have to go to the breast clinic to discuss the results of my latest MRI. I was due to have surgery in Feb - mastectomy with immediate reconstruction via DIEP - but because of an "anomaly" on my spine it was postponed. (Subsequent tests showed it was merely degeneration, so the op could have gone ahead. Since then my husband has started chemo for his liver/stomach cancer having just had session 4 out of 12.  I really would like to go ahead with the immediate reconstruction (if still offered), but not sure how we will cope if I'm out of action for such a long recovery period? I do the driving as he's not strong enough, and although he hasn't had side effects from his chemo, some days he is very weak. If I had the mastectomy and delayed the rest - what's the usual time between ops? How long does it take to recover from the mastectomy itself?  I'd be VERY grateful for any insights others could give me. I know it's almost like "how long is a piece of string" questions, but any help might get rid of my butterflies for today! Sandie
Posts.Title: Today's the day!

Posts.Content: I am home from a very long afternoon sat in our local hospital! DH had an appointment for removal of hid chemo bottle which was almost an hour late, so I left him and ran to my appt in another part of the hospital. To be told that BC appts were running an hour late, so I ran back to find DH and then walking back to my BC appt!  Doctor told me that the MRI results I had done last Thursday weren't back yet ! (Why didn't they make the appointment for a week earlier?) Anyway after a physical exam of the affected breast, he seemed to think that the Letrozole was doing it's job as the breast seemed to be softer - so obviously doing it's job. Once he sees the MRI results next Tuesday, he will get the BC nurse to ring me and discuss how I want to proceed. As DH has just finished chemo 4 out of 12, he offered to extend the medication route for perhaps 3 months, which would allow his treatment to finish before I had any surgery. So now we have several days when we can discuss what might be best in our situation. After wanting the mastectomy and recon done in one go, I'm now leaning towards 2 separate ops. He did say there was probably going to be radiotherapy after mastectomy, so it would be better I suppose if DH had finished his treatment, otherwise we'll be spending days up there at a time!  Thanks for the advice/comments earlier. Hope your conversation is positive next week Sandie x
Posts.Title: Today's the day!

Posts.Content: Thanks Jo. I'm making a list of questions for this afternoon! I'll ask about the idea of temporary surgery. Will let you know what's said! Sandie
Posts.Title: Today's the day!

Posts.Content: Mazzie5 I was able to drive myself to and from each of my 15 sessions. Granted by the end I came home and collapsed on the sofa for an hour or so, but I would not say that I felt I was unsafe to drive. Of course it depends how far you have to drive home. And don't forget to ask if they offer free parking at the hospital for radiotherapy patients! I finished my treatment on March 26th and for the first week after treatment I was wiped out, but apart from a "sunburnt area" I now feel fine with it all.
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Radiotherapy Chat***

Posts.Content: Good Morning everyone! As there  have been no recent posts, I'm assuming everyone is doing ok with their rads? Or have we just given up??  I finished mine last month, but since then have developed the dreaded rash and itchyness. Remembering what I was told on my last session, I bought some hydrocortisone cream and have been applying it regularly, but now - 3 weeks later - it's still there! It's right at the top of the area they radiated in the centre of my chest and just a bit under my collar bone so it's visible when I wear an open necked shirt or lower t-shirt. I've been covering it in aloe vera gel and moisturiser every time I think about it. What I really want to know I suppose is - is this normal? How long does it carry on for? I don't want to bother the nurses if all they say is keep creaming it!  On another side note, I have my second session with my Macmillan counsellor today - I felt sorry for the poor guy at our first session as I spent 50 minutes pouring out the story of the last two and a half years! But it felt so good to be able to open up to someone who would not judge how I was dealing with it all. And yesterday someone from the Hospice bereavement service rang me. Although Mike never made it to the hospice, the nurse at the hospital had referred me to them. She offered me some group sessions once I finish my one to one sessions, and sounded really positive that I would find it beneficial. So I'll investigate that later too. Anyway, I hope everyone is doing ok. There is a light at the end of the gloomy tunnel. And I hope that you all have a happy Easter.
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Radiotherapy Chat***

Posts.Content: Thanks Granny59 and Aliblue for your prompt replies. I will have to ring my BC nurse tomorrow and see what she says. I was hoping to have had the appointment through to see the oncologist, then I'd just pop into the unit! With my husband's liver and stomach cancer and now this I seem to be living there over the last 2 years!! I'm sure this is just the fluid building up but today the area under the breast (where the bottom of my bra sits) is quite tender. It almost feels like a horrendous bruise. And my arm is numb now from armpit down to elbow. Does it ease or is it permanently like that?
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Good grief! Last Thursday they drained 1060ml. Today there was another 750ml!! Where is it all coming from??  The advanced nurse practitioner saw me, and reassured me that the "lump" I could feel was just tissue left in the breast after the op. She also reassured me that the numbness may well lessen, but it is unlikely to go completely from the armpit. So like you Aliblue, I'll be looking where I'm spraying the deodorant! So until I see the oncologist on Weds all my questions have been answered. Thanks everyone
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: BC nurse just rung and I am being "fitted in" to a clinic this afternoon to get it drained again!!
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Well I have rung the BC nurse this morning and left a message to call me back. I also sent her an email yesterday explaining it, just in case I missed her call (cannot get a signal in our Tesco and have to go to GP with DH later too!) I also got the appointment to see the oncologist this morning in the post. Next Weds 19th - and he will talk me through all the options. Will update once I know more and have decided what route to take.
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: On 20th August I had a right side mastectomy and lymph node removal. Ten days later I had over a litre of fluid drained, (I had no drains in hospital). apart from the 7 tumours removed 3 of the lymph nodes were also cancerous, so I have been told I need to see the oncologist to discuss chemo, radiotherapy and hormone treatment (as well as an Asprin trial??)  Anyway last night I noticed a small hard lump has formed on the underside of the breast tissue. The seroma is building again, so I need to get that drained, but is this kind of lump normal? The funny thing is that before my mammogram I couldn't feel ANY lumps in the breast itself, so my diagnosis was a complete shock to me.
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Cannon  I finally worked out how to post pictures here so here is my Moon Hare that I worked on while DH was in hospital. Although I have worked on quite large pieces for a while, this one definitely took my concentration (about 90 colours in it!) I bought a tabletop daylight lamp from Amazon which helped a lot during those winter months too!  Just home from another clinic appointment (will post more in a separate thread) but treated myself to a skein of DK and some DP needles to try knitting a knocker over the weekend! Take care
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Thanks taralou. It is hung beside our bed, so that I can look at it every morning and evening. It reminds me that I have the strength to get through most things - so sorry it won't be finding it's way to your wall soon! xx
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Kumihimo - thank you for the compliment! I just do it because I enjoy it. My house is full, my family have loads and my granddaughter is fast becoming my major recipient!! I am currently working on a much smaller piece but the colours are darker - it's a small dragon hanging in a Christmas stocking! Might be done by then!! I do have a blog where I show some of my finishes if you would be interested? It's not had a lost posted over the last yer because of all the upheaval in our lives, but I'm trying to get back into it monthly at least!
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: toxophilite I am in awe of an engineered wedding dress! I sewed my own (43 years ago), but I didn't go down the traditional white meringue style dress!  I was taught to sew by my parents - mum was a machinist for a shirt manufacturer and had an industrial machine at home. Dad was a manager in the same shirt firm - he started as a van boy there, went off to the army in WW2 and came back to the same firm. He used to draft the patterns, before finally making it to manager before he retired. On a side note do you ever suffer from pains in your torso from the cocodamol? I have had painful ribs and back since I took a couple overnight for hip pain.  There is some serious talent amongst us here! Love everyone's work.
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Ronstar - Pinterest is such a rabbit hole I feel like Alice in Wonderland falling down it - only never to reappear. One note of caution though Pinterest is well-known for not policing copyright! Too many people post patterns (even full cross stitch patterns) there, and of course that then deprives the original designer of the purchase price. So just be careful out there! I have a board for cross stitch, but I am careful to post only the finished article, never a full pattern UNLESS I can confirm myself that it is a genuine freebie. Meanwhile everyone keep crafting! Sandie
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Thanks for the link and info on the knocker pattern Kacang. I've been a lifelong crafter and these last few years it has been my salvation. When husband was diagnosed with bowel cancer in Dec 2016, I had just started a large cross stitch (well just over A4 sized), but working on that and a knitted mermaid tail for my granddaughter's Christmas present kept me sane! I was diagnosed with lymph node grade 2 BC just after Christmas this year and again, cross stitch has saved my sanity. It's wonderful how many times you can stab something in the name of embroidery and get away with it!  Ha Ha!  I've also joined a group on Facebook that paints pictures on rocks and pebbles, then leaves them in places for others to find - Love on the rocks it's called. It's amazing how much joy can be given to someone by a simple piece of art on a pebble. Check it out!
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: grannylara I have sent you a friend request as your profile sounds just like me! As I'm not sure if the board allows us to post links to blogs, I'll send it to you privately somehow? Not quite sure yet what I can and can't do on here!! Meanwhile if you check online for "Tigermum's creative corner" you might find it!  I generally use 18ct Aida, but have been venturing into some hand-dyed fabrics lately. Like you I have boxes of kits I bought many years ago, some have been in boxes in our shed for about 5 years! But I also tend to buy the pattern and use my own collection of threads.
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: @jmp - that jumper looks so appealing just now with the weather we're having. Mind you global warming would probably make it unnecessary by the time I'd finished knitting it! Ha Ha!!
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Thanks grannylara. It is cross stitched. I started it just before Christmas 2016 and finished it in about 6 months. It was what kept me sane while DH was in hospital for 12 weeks!
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Oh that's pretty Jenny. And nicely framed too. I'm plugging away at my HAED storykeep design. This photo is from last week so I've done a bit more since then. It's helping to keep me calm. Had ANOTHER MRI yesterday (on my spine!) so need to keep busy whille waiting for results!
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Don't know about dog coats but I quite fancy one of those Aran jumpers for me! At least it would be great for the days when I'm not emitting enough heat to keep a power station going! Sandie
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Thanks Frances. Getting a bit late here today to go and hide in my "craft room" (AKA the box room! ) But tomorrow I'll have a hunt through my fabrics to see what might suit. I'll remember your tips though. Gentle return hugs Sandie
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: @kumihimo That's  a fab idea. I had my SN removal at the end of Jan, with a view to mastectomy and DIEP reconstruction mid Feb. But the SN revealed cancer cells, so the day before my op, it was cancelled to do more tests. However 2 months down the line I have been getting pain at the lower end of my underarm scar over the last few days. Not sure of it's just because of the cold, damp weather or something else. As I can't speak to a BCN over the Easter weekend, I might try something like this to see if it will help. Care to share what you used? What did you fill it with? How long do you heat it for? Thanks for the inspiration
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Weeblemum - I love dragons too! But I tend to concentrate on one main piece at a time. I might stitch a few cards or ornaments at the same time because it gives me a break, especially if there's lot of one colour to work through! Post a pic of your St George piece at some point - love to see it. Sandie
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Thank you so much Kacang! Just got to find some nice Christmas fabric to finish her off Sandie
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: You will come through this and be fine. As mentioned, each individual's needs are taken into account. I needed to delay my surgery to allow for my husband's chemo - the surgeon allowed me to start on hormone therapy and then when DH finished his cycles, I asked for an appointment and told them "surgery ASAP please". Within 2 weeks I had my mastectomy, and surgeon was able to tell me that although there were 7 tumours, he had got it all. Now I wait to see oncologist tomorrow and see what my next steps are! So be confident, they know what they are doing, they will talk you through step by step, and of your BC nurse is as good as mine, she will sit and hold your hand as long as you need. Good luck!
Posts.Title: MRI results & surgery / treatment plan tomorrow

Posts.Content: Ronstar those look really pretty. I have never tried felting. Please let us see a photo of the finished work if you can. Meanwhile I've finished a cross stitch which I'm going to make into a cushion for my GD who fractured her arm before Easter. Luckily it's healing well, and she's now just in tubigrip rather than plaster. Found some unicorn fabric to make it into a cushion for her. It needs a quick freshen up and a press, then I'll finish it off. Sandie
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: Been rushing around like a maniac lately. Husband started his chemo on 24th April, on a 2 weekly cycle, so that 4 appointments every 2 weeks!! And then I have got to have an MRI tomorrow to check on my BC before a clinic appointment next week. But I have found time to finish off my cross stitch Magical Arrival dragon. I will make her into a wall hanging and display her nearer Christmas. I'm calling her a a dragonette - maybe naming her Kaida. She looks too sweet to grow up to be a big nasty dragon!!
Posts.Title: Crafts and BC
